newsitem.title: BOSNIA: Bosnian Moslem leaders mark independence day.
newsitem.headline: Bosnian Moslem leaders mark independence day.

text.p: Bosnian Moslem leaders visited the graves of dead soldiers on Saturday to mark the fifth anniversary of Bosnia's declaration of independence from former Yugoslavia.

"I am proud that five years ago we did not give in to all those threats and that we voted for freedom, despite everything," Alija Izetbegovic, Moslem chairman of the country's collective presidency, said in a statement.
"The price was high, incalculably high, but we could not keep on living with our heads bent down," added Izetbegovic, who led the drive for independence.

Bosnian Moslems and Croats voted on March 1, 1992 to secede from Serbian-led Yugoslavia in a referendum which cleared the way for international recognition. Most Bosnian Serbs boycotted the referendum.
War erupted a month later. Bosnian Serb forces, backed by the Yugoslav army, laid siege to the capital Sarajevo and moved to seize control of strategic towns.
Izetbegovic, and the Moslem co-chairman of the new Council of Ministers, Haris Silajdzic, visited Sarajevo's Kovaci cemetry to pay tribute to soldiers killed during the siege of the capital.
Newspaper commentaries said the country had yet to achieve full independence after the 3-1/2 year war, which ended with a peace treaty in 1995.
Sarajevo still had no control over most of the country's international borders and Serb authorities had effectively refused to recognise the authority of the central government, the newspapers said.
"During the war, Bosnia-Herzegovina managed to withstand a total division," said a commentary published in the daily Oslobodjenje. "Now it is facing a political battle for genuine independence."
